issues.title: How to do encryption without integrity in message_2
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
The current specification generates a long encryption key and perform XOR cipher.

As there are no non-AEAD algorithms in COSE, other options are a bit more complex.

- Remove the tag from AEAD ciphertext. Only works when AEAD has a well-defined tag.
- Ascociate a IND-CPA encryption algorithm with each AEAD. Requires a table.

AES-CCM -> AES
AES-GCM -> AES
ChaCha20-Poly1305 -> ChaCha20

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: As the Responder sends its identity to an unauthenticated part, there is no need to have IND-CCA against active attackers. IND-CPA encryption is enough in this case. See full SIGMA paper for more information.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: Should we define the encryption to that it can be performed by removing the tag.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
Specifying an specific AES-CTR and ChaCha20 stream cipher mode makes it cumbersome for implementors....

EDHOC need to encrypt more data than DTLS 1.3 and cannot rely on AES-ECB and the ChaCha20 block cipher.

I think the right way to do this in a way easy for developers (which we want) is to just remove the tag....

If there would ever be a future COSE AEAD that does not have a well defined tag, it would be needed to define how encryption without integrity is done.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
Commit 6469cb8 changes the Table solution to a remove tag solution.

https://github.com/lake-wg/edhoc/commit/6469cb8dd1865eb19ad049c28b3781688fcb1aef

Looking at the changes give a good overview of the two solutions.

Having implemented both, I have a preference to just removing the tag from the COSE_Encrypt.

Using AES-CTR or ChaCha20 stream cipher requires far more work from the implementor. The developer would have to find the raw AES and ChaCha20 functions and make sure to implement the stream ciphers. This is doable but a bit complicated. We would like to keep implementation simple.

The solution with deriving a long key and XORing was simple but raised a lot of questions as XOR encryption has in the past been used in insecure ways (repeating a short key....). HMAC-SHA-256 on the other hand could very have higher security bounds than AES-128-CTR.

I think just removing the tag is the best overall solution. It works for all current and foreseeable AEAD in COSE. It is very easy to implement for the developer and it does not raise any questions like old HMAC-SHA-256+XOR solution

Would be good with other peoples opinion on this

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
For -04 we are reverting back to -02. That seems like the easiest solution given that COSE does not support any IND-CPA encrytion algorithms (COSE itself does not need that). We do not want people to change their implementations unless we are sure that there will be a change.

Using HKDF as a binary additive stream cipher is perfectly secure, in fact it is a much better stream cipher than AES-CTR. The reason that AES-CTR is used is that something like HKDF-Expand is overkill security wise for simple encryption and much much slower that AES-CTR.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
much much slower is for long messages.... for very short messages is would actually be faster. For the short message_2 speed difference is negligible.

Another reasons HKDF-Expand is not typically used is that most application require both IND-CCA2 confidentiality as well as integrity protection. Both of which are given by an AEAD.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: Fixed in -04?

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: No objections or comments to the -04 version. -05 test vectors implement this

issues.title: Register ciphersuites with high security
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
There has been interest to use EDHOC with high level security, i.e. AES-256 and 384 bit ECC.

Should we register a CNSA compliant cipher suite?
(A256GCM, SHA-384, P-384, ES384, P-384, A256GCM, SHA-384)

And/or something alternative?
(A256GCM, SHAKE256, X448, EdDSA, Ed448, A256GCM, SHAKE256)
(ChaCha20/Poly1305, SHAKE256, X448, EdDSA, Ed448, ChaCha20/Poly1305, SHAKE256)

The document should be more clear that it is possible to use EDHOC with any registered COSE algorithms by using a private number for the cipher suite.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
I'm proxying input on two new proposed cipher suites:

Array: 11, 6, 2, -35, 2, 11, 6
Desc: AES-CCM-16-64-256, SHA-384, P-384, ES384, P-384, AES-CCM-16-64-256, SHA-384
 
Array: 13, 6, 2, -35, 2, 13, 6
Desc: AES-CCM-64-64-256, SHA-384, P-384, ES384, P-384, AES-CCM-64-64-256, SHA-384

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
AES-CCM-16-64-256 and AES-CCM-64-64-256 are quite odd algorithms. Combining 256 bit keys with 64 bit tags is quite unbalanced. TLS WG has dicussed and decided to not standardize any more such algorithms.

People can already use them as private cipher suites, but I do not see that it is something that can be recommended in general. I think:

(A256GCM, SHA-384, P-384, ES384, P-384, A256GCM, SHA-384)
(ChaCha20/Poly1305, SHAKE256, X448, EdDSA, Ed448, ChaCha20/Poly1305, SHAKE256)

would be the reasonable high security cipher suites to register. The first of these which aligns with CNSA I think should be registered.

comments.author: lemikev
comments.body:
Hi Emanjon.

I'm the one who asked for "AES-CCM-64-64-256, SHA-384, P-384, ES384, P-384, AES-CCM-64-64-256, SHA-384".
The goal was effectively to be CNSA aligned.
I agree with your comments and "A256GCM, SHA-384, P-384, ES384, P-384, A256GCM, SHA-384" is perfectly find for my needs.
To cover CNSA, it might be logical to also include "A128GCM, SHA-256, P-256, ES256, P-256, A128GCM, SHA-256".
Just a suggestion, I don't correctly have a need for it.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
We had a similar request some weeks ago, so I go ahead and make a commit for "A256GCM, SHA-384, P-384, ES384, P-384, A256GCM, SHA-384".

A128GCM, SHA-256, P-256, ES256, P-256, A128GCM, SHA-256" used to be in Suite B, but is no longer in CNSA. I Agree that it probably makes sense to add something between CNSA and Constrained CCM_8. I will bring up the question in an upcoming LAKE meeting. I think the algorithms used on state of the art web servers today is typically:
A128GCM, SHA-256, Curve25519, ES256, P-256, A128GCM, SHA-256

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: I made a commit e3dc83b registering two more cipher suites. One aligning with CNSA and one aligning with current best practice for HTTPS (used e.g. by GitHub). I also added more information on the posibility of using private cipher suites.

comments.author: lemikev
comments.body: Thanks for this change. Please send advise if somebody else is implementing "A256GCM, SHA-384, P-384, ES384, P-384, A256GCM, SHA-384". I will be interested to interop with him.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: Fixed in -03

issues.title: Add guidelines for distinguishing received messages. Relates to #30.
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
Proxying draft solution:

    First, check if it is an Error Message. That's the case if and only
    if the first or second element of the sequence is a text string.

    If it's not an Error Message:

    - If the sequence has 1 or 2 elements, it's Message 3.

    - If the sequence has 3 elements, it's Message 2.

    - If the sequence has 5 elements, it's message 1.

    - If the sequence has 4 elements, check its second element.
    --- If it is an array or an integer, it's Message 1.
    --- If it is a byte string, it's Message 2.

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body:
Since both a client and a server can act as Initiator or Responder, this early understanding helps in taking the next steps when receiving a message.

This helps especially for retrieving the status of an ongoing EDHOC execution when receiving Error Message, Message 2 or Message 3, or for starting processing Message 1 that potentially yields the creation and storage of a new execution status as Responder.

For the status retrieval, the endpoint uses C_I/C_R (if included in the message) or implicit transport protocol indications, depending on the correlation method.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: I think these are good points, but I don't see exactly why you are having a problem and how the draft should be updated. Could you provide a conrete message flow that also shows which protocol layers that are used below EDHOC. Could be that normative text on how to distinguish the messages are needed, or this is mostly implementation guidance. Might also be that something in the draft needed to be more strict or change. I think both endpoints sending message_1 has not been discussed other than from a security perspective.

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: It is just for implementation guidance, as a possible way to do the message distinction. I didn't think of something to add or fix in the actual protocol.

comments.author: chrysn
comments.body:
I'd prefer not to parse the full message (which, given it's CBOR sequences, ) at the point where I branch around; looking at the decision tree from that side.

I'm only considering a server's situation here, so it can receive a Message 1, a Message 3 (carrying a c_r, of the server's choice), or a Message 2 or 4 (both carrying a c_i, with a value of the server's choice).

Such a server WOULD PROBABLY pick c_i and c_r values which it can distinguish from each other (say, by their least significant bit, or by a prefix), and WOULD PROBABLY NOT pick any value that's a legal METHOD_CORR (ie. no values from 0 to 15 inclusive).

The server can then tell whether it's
* Message 1: first element in 0..=15
* Message 3: first element is a C_R
* Message 2: first element is a C_I
* Message 4: does that ever get used with a server at all?

  Probably not, as "In deployments where no protected application message is sent from the Responder to the Initiator" is not the case -- because that's one of the cases where it is not needed.

  If s, the distinction between message 2 and 4 is "is it over after having decoded the two elements" (given message 4 has 2 elements in presence of a C_I, message 2 has 4).

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: Provided by transport. In -08 this is described for CoAP in Appendix A.3.

issues.title: Section 3 and 4.1-4.2 needs restructure
issues.author: gselander
issues.body:
The structure of sections 2, 3 and 4.1-4.2 is reflecting old versions of the protocol: New methods have been added and the symmetric key authentication variant has been removed.

Some examples of why this is needed:
* Section 4 is described as containing the asymmetric key authentication variant although the current protocol only supports asymmetric key authentication. There are two sections labelled as "overview" (3 and 4.1) with overlap in content and unclear division of content. Section 2 already contains an overview.

* Figure 3 in section 3 is not very helpful to explain the protocol components, replace with figure 4 from section 4.

A restructure is needed, some initial ideas:

* Keep section 2 largely as is but change title to "EDHOC outline" and mention other methods
* Rename section 3 "Protocol components" and move corresponding content here
* Rename section 4 "Messages formatting and processing" and focus on that

issues.title: Test vectors not adhering to section 4.4.3 (cipher suite verification by the Responder in message 1)
issues.author: TimothyClaeys
issues.body:
In the following test vector:

https://github.com/lake-wg/edhoc/blob/c73dc6affe2d7a47fa8eac97be4d4bbd8bd7c667/test-vectors/vectors.txt#L2520

The Responder supports all 4 cipher suites (0, 1, 2, 3). The Initiator sends a message 1, where it includes 0, 1, and 2 as supported cipher suites and selects cipher suite 1. According to [section 4.4.3 ](https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-lake-edhoc-02#section-4.4), the Responder must verify that the selected cipher suite is supported and that no prior cipher suites in SUITES_I are supported.

Since the Responder supports cipher suite 0 and cipher suite 0 also has a higher preference for the Initiator (it appears as the first element in SUITES_I), the Responder should answer with and EDHOC error message.

The test vector can be fixed by removing cipher suite 0 from the Responder's supported cipher suites.

comments.body:
Two other test vectors with the same issue:

https://github.com/lake-wg/edhoc/blob/c73dc6affe2d7a47fa8eac97be4d4bbd8bd7c667/test-vectors/vectors.txt#L2820

https://github.com/lake-wg/edhoc/blob/c73dc6affe2d7a47fa8eac97be4d4bbd8bd7c667/test-vectors/vectors.txt#L3075

issues.title: Sections 1.0 and 1.1 needs restructure
issues.author: gselander

Sections 1.1 and the text before section 1.1 in section 1 (=1.0) is overlapping, reflecting that section 1.1 has been added without harmonization of the existing text. Some  pieces are duplicate, other parts are redundant because they contain alternative reasoning with the same conclusion.

issues.title: Clarify decryption of CIPHERTEXT_2
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
In the latest version -03, Section 5.3.3 says:

"Decrypt CIPHERTEXT_2 by computing an outer COSE_Encrypt0 as defined in see Section 5.3.2 and XORing CIPHERTEXT_2 with the 'ciphertext' of the outer COSE_Encrypt0 with the tag removed."


Could you clarify this process and elaborate on its steps?

Also, is this actually involving a XORing? That seems being left here from the previous process in version -02 based on a keystream.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
Note that the operation to encrypt message_2 is not determined yet. We are awaiting developer feedback if the -02 or -03 way of doing things are the best way from a development perspective.

Could you clarify what is missing or unclear in the -03 description? The -03 description seems correct to me. XOR is needed in more or less all modern encryption.

(Feedback that AES-CTR and ChaCha20 stream cipher without Poly1305 is the right way is also ok of course. I found that alternative way to complex to implement).

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body:
Trying to rewrite that sentence as steps, I read it as:

1. Fill an Encrypt0 object like the one in Section 5.3.2 and encrypt it.

2. Take the resulting 'ciphertext' of the processed object and remove the tag.

3. Take the output of step 2 and XOR it with CIPHERTEXT_2 from Message_2.

The result of step 3 is the plaintext with ID_CRED_R, Signature_or_MAC_2 and possibly AD_2.


Is this the intended workflow? If so, what is used as plaintext P in step 1?

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
Yes, that is the intended workflow.

The value of P is clearly missing, P needs to be set to a byte string of zeroes of the same length as the intitial byte string, which the reciever would need to calculate as the length of the ciphertext minus the length of the tag. This is clearly missing from the text. 

Thanks.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
Maybe this removing tag is a bit more complex that I first thought. It actually requires two things from the AEAD. That is has a well-defined tag and that the encryption is done with a synchronous xor based stream cipher. Both of these happen to be true for all the currently defined AEAD algs.

Might very well be that we should for the -02 version if that is easier. I think that solution fine if we reformulate it that we are using HMAC-SHA256 as a stream cipher to generate keystream. The reason nobody does that is that HMAC-SHA256 is overkill security wise and are slow.

Another alternative would be to use AES-CTR but then I think that should not be left to the developers and instead registered as an algorithm in COSE.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: Or rather we are using HKDF-Expand as a stream cipher to generate key stream

issues.title: Terminology for ciphertext/authentication tag
issues.author: gselander
issues.body:
Comment from implementer that the use of the term ciphertext is confusing.

EDHOC reuses terminology from RFC 6655 where the term ciphertext denote ciphertext concatenated with authentication tag.

RFC 6655:
"The AEAD_AES_128_CCM_8 ciphertext consists of the ciphertext output of
   the CCM encryption operation concatenated with the 8-octet
   authentication tag output of the CCM encryption operation. "

Since -03 the protocol contains instances of three uses of the term ciphertext:
1. the output of the encryption only (= ciphertext)
2. the authentication tag only (= ciphertext, in case of empty plaintext), and 
3. the concatenation of these (= ciphertext according to RFC 6655).

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: 7f1e2310 addresses this issue by clarifying the the notation 'ciphertext'.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
I think we need to discuss and document how the EDHOC processing should be done. This is unfortunatly a bit missing from the document so I understand all the issues regarding this. In the document the processin is written under each message which probably gives the idea that the implementation has to know the message to do processing.

I dont think my previous statement "think a undocumented design philosophy was that first element should be used to distinguish message_1 and message_3. This aspect dissapeared with the bstr_identifier optimization." was true. 

Thinking some more, I think the idea when writing the spec was as follows.

```
- First detemine that is is a EDHOC message.

- Retrieve the security context using the connection identifier and/or other external information such as the CoAP Token and the 5-tuple.

IF security context was found
      - IF messege is error, process as error
      - ELSE process as expected next message in security context
ELSE process as message_1
```
The issue suggesting message_3 several times makes me a bit worried. I cannot see any concrete attacks but it is definitly not intended and might break the security properties.

issues.title: Max retransmissions of EDHOC messages
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
Thinking of CoAP for transport:

1. Let's say that the Initiator (Responder) trasmits Message_1 (Message_2) as a Confirmable message, does not receive an ACK from the other peer and retransmits the message. This happens again multiple times, until the maximum number of retransmissions is reached. Should the sender peer simply discontinue the protocol?

2. Let's say that the same as above happens with the Initiator (Responder) transmitting Message_3 (Message_4). Should the sender peer delete PRK_4x3m, TH_4 and any possible application keys derived with the exporter, including the possible OSCORE Security Context?

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: @marco-tiloca-sics Can we close this?

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body:
I understand that the details on retransmission and reliability are left to the used transport, but I couldn't find indications on what to do if a session "gets stuck" before completing.

If the next expected message does not come before a timeout possibly influenced by the used transport, I suppose this can be seen as a failure, followed by discontinuing the protocol as in other cases, so that memory and state can be freed up, and especially the allocated connection identifier can be made available again. When this involves message_3 or message_4, this possibly extends to deleting application key material already derived from PRK_4x3m and TH_4.

I'm not sure if it's worth also sending an Error Message after that, but it would be at least consistent with what is done in other situations where the protocol is discontinued.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
It is not clear to me what the specification should write here. 

Failure in transport is out of scope for EDHOC. That the EDHOC implementation needs to get informed that transport failed to be able to free state is probably obvious?

Similarly, in order to free state of existing exporter secret or OSCORE security context, the EDHOC implementation need to get informed about it being obsolete. The OSCORE security context may expire because e.g. because exceeding the number of allowed encryptions, but there may also be  policies about lifetime out of scope of EDHOC.

The case that the endpoint sending the last message of the protocol does not know if it reached the other endpoint seems to belong to either of these two cases.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: @marco-tiloca-sics Considering  the changes made -08, is there any further clarification needed in the specification, for EDHOC in general or for CoAP in particular?

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body:
Reading this with fresh eyes, now I think that my points are basically covered in Section 5.1 "Message Processing Outline", already before version -08, where:

* > The protocol state is assumed to be associated to an applicability statement ... which provides the context for how messages are transported ...

  explicitly involves the used transport, whatever it is and whatever the way it works.

* > If the processing fails, then the protocol is discontinued, an error message sent, and the protocol state erased.

  does mention the cleanup I had in mind.


So a "processing failure" can also be the result of a "transport failure", e.g., not receiving an expected next message by a certain timeout or exceeding the maximum number of admitted retransmissions.

The only possible clarification can be making this point explicit here, otherwise it seems to be already fine as is.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: The text in Section 5.1 "Message Processing Outline" is quite general. I added "for some reason" to "If the processing fails" without going into the specific detail of that it may be lack of confirmation on transport layer.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: Looks like this can be closed.

issues.title: Loss of Message_4
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
Thinking of CoAP for transport, let's say that the Responder sends Message_4 as a Non-Confirmable message, and this never reaches the Initiator.

One can expect the Initiator to eventually resend Message_3. When the Responder receives this Message_3, it has to resend the same Message_4 as above. However, it can come to understand what to do in two possible ways:

1. It stores a full copy of Message_3 upon first receiving it, to check for a perfect match against the retransmitted one. This copy has to be stored until the first protected application-message is received from the Initiator.

2. After having processed the first Message_3 for the first time, it keeps storing PRK_3e2m and TH_3 until the first protected application-message is received from the Initiator. Then, when receiving the retransmitted Message_3, the Responder can just process it again as it did when receiving it the first time.

Which is preferable? The first one costs more in terms of storage, but it still allows the Responder to delete the temporary PRK_3e2m and TH_3 as soon as possible, i.e. when it has completed the processing of the first received Message_3.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
Good questions and points.

From an pure EDHOC perspective, the lower layers does not really matter. After message_3 has been received and processed, the Responder should never process message_3 again and PRK_3e2m and TH_3 will have been deleted.

I think 2. violated the EDHOC protocol.

I think 1. is not needed. I dont think the responder needs to check message_3 again. The Initiator must not change message_3. If message_3 is changed things break, which is fine.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: @marco-tiloca-sics Can we close this?

issues.title: REST code for EDHOC Error Message as CoAP response
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
The following is a possible exchange that might happen, if using the "EDHOC-in-OSCORE" optimization proposed in [1].

1. The Initiator (as CoAP client) sends an OSCORE-protected request, embedding both EDHOC Message 3 and the actual request payload protected with the just-established Security Context, as per the proposed approach.

2. The Responder (as CoAP server) processes EDHOC Message 3. If this processing fails, the Responder replies with an unprotected EDHOC error message. As of today, this would be a 2.04 response, hence a successful response for CoAP.

However, as per [2], "A successful response to a request with the OSCORE option SHALL contain the OSCORE option." Thus, when receiving the unprotected 2.04 response above, the Initiator would experience an OSCORE failure, which is fine and consistent per se.

However, if the OSCORE processing happens before the EDHOC processing on the Initiator, it might become impossible to access and process the actual response content, i.e. the EDHOC Error Message. Whether which of the two processing comes first is implementation specific.

An easy way out would be to rather have the EDHOC Error Message sent as a CoAP error response. On the Initiator, the response would then be not discarded by OSCORE, and would ensure a correct processing of the EDHOC Error Message.

[1] https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-palombini-core-oscore-edhoc/
[2] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc8613#section-2

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
First update of text on transport of error message, see 75d8dd7.
@marco-tiloca-sics Please comment.

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body:
In general, it would be good to better understand what issues are avoided when cross-protocol proxies are used.

Otherwise, the new content can be split and rephrased as follows, i.e. part as general and part as specific to CoAP.

[Section 6.1 - "EDHOC Error Message]

An EDHOC error message can be sent by either endpoint as a reply to any non-error EDHOC message. How errors at the EDHOC layer are transported depends on lower layers, which need to enable error messages to be sent and processed as intended.

EDHOC errors sent as transport-successful messages can avoid issues created by usage of cross protocol proxies (e.g. UDP to TCP).

[Section 7.2 "Transferring EDHOC in CoAP"]

EDHOC errors SHOULD be sent as POST requests and 2.04 (Changed) responses. An exception is the combined EDHOC-in-OSCORE case {{I-D.palombini-core-oscore-edhoc}}, where an error message response following a combined EDHOC message_3/OSCORE request needs to be sent with a CoAP error code.

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: Following on the original comment and building on more recent discussions, another advantage of having EDHOC Error Messages as CoAP error responses is that they would become cacheable.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
I think we have addressed this issue. We have removed the statement about avoiding cross protocol proxies (92d9a98d) which wasn't clear, tuned down the requirement on transport (41cf0e9fe) and moved OSCORE processing to the CoRE draft. 

I close this issue now, we can always reopen if there is something we missed.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
I made a PR to begin to adress this problem #106. This was an old know issue that was not transfered from the old GitHub repository.

In the PR is it explained that algorithms might have parameters and that parameters need to be included so hat the algorithm is determined.

While making the PR, it struck me that the signature algorithm curve is not needed at all and in COSE and X.509 terms this is determined by the public key algorithm. I think this needs to be addresses. Either we remove the signature curve from the cipher suite completely or we specify it as a profiling of the public key. Profiling the public key is however problematic as it is not a COSE key and may be any PKIX algorithm that may not even be standardized for COSE at all. I do not think there is any reason to restrict PKIX.

My suggestion is that we remove the public key parameters from the cipher suite.

comments.body:
"Applicability Statement Template" - I think it should be understood in the following way. This appendix lists the different protocol parameters and settings that the application needs to ensure are configured/agreed between the endpoints. An "applicability statement" corresponds to a configuration with certain settings. An applicability statement template is a template for what are the parameters and settings that needs to be specified and guidance for how to set them.

Other proposals for title are welcome.

comments.body:
Mailthread in iotops:
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/iotops/KcWcK19kACOYnimRqFNJDBu_MAk/

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
Proposal after discussion in Hackathon:

error = (
  ? C_x : bstr_identifier,
    DIAG_MSG : tstr,
    ERR_CODE : int / 2* int,
  ? SUITES_R : [ supported : 2* suite ] / suite,
)

Top-level ERR_CODEs:

(0. Success)
1. Message field error (syntax error or incorrect protocol field of expected message)
2. Selected cipher suite not supported (include SUITES_R in message)
3. Credential/context error (error related to establish certificate/raw public key context for processing message, including certificate expired, revoked, unsupported, corrupt, unknown CA, or other issue in processing the credential)
4. Decrypt error (a cryptographic operation failed, including being unable to correctly verify a signature or a MAC in the protocol message)
5. Auxiliary data error (unsupported or missing auxiliary data)
6. Access denied (credential valid but peer not allowed access)
7. Internal error (error not related to the protocol or the peer)

Selected comments during Hackathon:
- Relation to errors on other layer, e.g. CoAP errors or error in application. 
- - EDHOC does not require CoAP so could have use for specified own errors.
- - Does "5. AD error" belong to EDHOC?  Perhaps, auxiliary data provides means for security applications to reuse EDHOC and this would be a channel to send errors in those applications. [Not sure if this helps but, alternatively, errors could be encoded as auxiliary data, which may require an AD-field in the error message]
- - Does "6. Access denied" belong to EDHOC? Perhaps, it provides a suitable error to the requirement "Verify that the identity of the Responder is an allowed identity for this connection"


Further comments are welcome. Happy to make the list shorter if possible.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
Other thoughts:

* We can put some of these error classes into an "x. unspecified error" bucket if we don't think they are not meaningful to act upon individually. 

* We can define a class of errors "y. general error" and allow implementations to use class y for any error, including those properly belonging to some class above. This would allow implementations to only support some of the specified errors above, potentially listed in the applicability statement. (That would render the list of classes above just a RECOMMENDATION.)

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
Many OSs, shells, and programming languages (e.g. C) use 0 for success and everthing non-zero (negative or positive) is considered an error. HTTP and Coap use postive numbers only where 2. or 2xx is considered success.

I think we should probably follow one of these convensions instead of making a new one.

The specification should also probably define that everything else than whatever we decide for success is considered an error.

As discussed during the last interim, I do not believe removing the link of draft-ietf-lake-edhoc with OSCORE is a good idea from the charter point of view of the LAKE WG.

I just went through the editor's version of draft-ietf-core-oscore-edhoc and here is my proposal forward:

* Create a new appendix in draft-ietf-lake-edhoc named "Use with OSCORE", say Appendix A.
* Move the content of Section 4 of draft-ietf-core-oscore-edhoc back to draft-ietf-lake-edhoc, to Appendix A.1.
* Merge the content of Section 3 of draft-ietf-core-oscore-edhoc with the content in Section 7.2 of draft-ietf-lake-edhoc. Move the result to Appendix A.2.

With that, draft-ietf-lake-edhoc contains all the information to implement EDHOC and use it to key OSCORE. draft-ietf-core-oscore-edhoc becomes streamlined and focuses on optimizing the specific use case when message_3 and OSCORE request are sent in the same CoAP message for performance reasons.

issues.title: Coding density for bstr_identifier
issues.author: chrysn
issues.body:
We could increase (by a factor of about 3) the number of identifier values encodable in 2-byte bstr_identifier -- if rather than treating them as a byte string toward the application, we treat them as distinct integer and bytes values.

As before, the same 1-byte values could be encoded (-24 to 23). Of the 2-byte long encodings, there there would be ~3x256 inhabited ones (unlike now, ~256): We could use the 256 `18 xx` (for xx > 24 as those would be encoded in a single byte), `38 xx` (again, xx < 24 staying uninhabited) and the `41 xx` (1-long byte strings) values.

Whether this makes implementation harder or easier is IMO dependent on the programming style; for me it'd make things easier. (Implementers can't store the value as a length-delimited bytestring with a custom encoder any more, but can still store the CBOR encoded item in an opaque string).

This would also allow applications that find it easier to work with small numbers to just use numeric identifiers for everything they mint themselves, and use these in lookup. (These then lose some of the benefits of identifier compression.)

comments.author: chrysn
comments.body:
Considering how the OSCORE extractor uses C_I and C_R, this would be problematic.

Options are:
1. Leave it as is -- with only ~256 2-byte C_x available
2. Allow arbitrary int / bstr as bstr_identifier, but move the text over to the OSCORE extraction to say that this mapping is applied between C_x and `kid`. That would leave the general applications with the wide possibilities, while OSCORE would have the 0-length KID in a 1-byte bstd_identifier, a few selected KIDs (00 to 18) also in the 1-byte bstr_identifier, and all the others in len+1 bstr_identifier slots.
3. Go for even more efficiency (but that has minimal returns at great complexity so is almost certainly not worth it)

I have a soft preference for 2, but 1 is probably fine as well -- given that OSCORE will be a main user of EDHOC and couldn't use the optimization.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: I think 2 is the right way to go. I think we should do that. I think the current specification of bstr_identifier is a bit complex. We have gotten several comment and questions regarding this. I think 2 make things simpler.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
I made a pull request for this issue. @chrysn check that the transformation between C_x and OSCORE ID is what you wanted. I did not see any point in making it more complex.

I just realized that we could expand the number of 1 byte excodings with almost 50 % by also allowing major type seven I.e.

C_x : bstr / int / #7 

(null is reserved for used by C_1)

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: Even with this change the bstr_identifier stays for its use in compressing ID_CRED_x when kid is used i.e. { 4 : kid_R }.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: Or maybe we can not use #7 as the values 0..19 are unassigned

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
This issue needs to wait until we have decided what to do with correlation. Suggestions on the table are diverse
- to leave it to lower layers
- make all C_x mandatory

comments.author: chrysn
comments.body:
Next step (from current discussion): provide PR, and describe (explicitly and locally) how an integer can encode for a `{4: x}` value. Then we can discuss further based on that.

Alternative: explain bstr_identifier better.

Other alternative: just let a bstr encode for `{4: x}` -- that allows having a single one-byte value still (rather than ~48), and 256 two-byte values. Good enough for the cases where there *is* one distinct to-be-optimized-for peer, and in how many cases is 48 enough?

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
>Other alternative: just let a bstr encode for {4: x} -- that allows having a single one-byte value still (rather than ~48), >and 256 two-byte values. Good enough for the cases where there is one distinct to-be-optimized-for peer, and in how >many cases is 48 enough?

That is a good observation. Might be useful with two values when the distinct to-be-optimized-for peer updates its key.


If bstr_identifier is not used for connection id, maybe the bstr_identifier section could be removed and replaced by:

* plaintext = ( ID_CRED_R / bstr / int, Signature_or_MAC_2, ? AD_2 )

* If ID_CRED_R contains a single 'kid' parameter, i.e., ID_CRED_R = { 4 : kid_R }, only the kid_R is conveyed in the plaintext. If ‘kid’ is in the interval h'00' to h'2f’, it is encoded as the corresponding integer minus 24, instead. I.e. { 4 : h’2a’ } is encoded as the integer 18, while { 4 : h'' } is encoded as h’’.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
Specifically for the 'kid' use of bstr_identifier, how about registering a new CBOR Header Parameter  (https://www.iana.org/assignments/cose/cose.xhtml) called, say, 'kid-int' with same function as 'kid' but where the value is a CBOR int instead of a CBOR bstr.

~~~~~~~~~~
   +-----------+-------+----------------+-------------+----------------+-------------------+
   | Name      | Label | Value Type     | Value       | Description    | Reference         |
   |           |       |                | Reference   |                |                   |
   +-----------+-------+----------------+-------------+----------------+-------------------+
   | kid-int   | TBD   | int            |             | Key identifier | [[This document]] |
   +-----------+-------+----------------+-------------+----------------+-------------------+
~~~~~~~~~~~

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: That is an interesting idea. Another alternative would be to expand the existing 'kid' in COSE to be bstr / int.

comments.author: chrysn
comments.body:
Both sound practical, and would make the WIP PR more readable. In an
ecosystem where thins are passed around as COSE objects, having
identifiers bstr/int does make sense. (Among other things, it allows
configuration storages to save their values in their pre-encoded compact
form).

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
I agree a single key identifier with value bstr / int is a better idea. In practice, how would we redefine 'kid' to be bstr / int? I assume it is too late to make the change in draft-ietf-cose-rfc8152bis-struct, so this would be a draft updating that RFC. Any compatibility issues with old and new implementations of 'kid'? 

Would it be an alternative to define a new key identifier:

~~~~~~~~~~
   +-----------+-------+----------------+-------------+----------------+-------------------+
   | Name      | Label | Value Type     | Value       | Description    | Reference         |
   |           |       |                | Reference   |                |                   |
   +-----------+-------+----------------+-------------+----------------+-------------------+
   | kid2      | TBD   | bstr / int     |             | Key identifier | [[This document]] |
   +-----------+-------+----------------+-------------+----------------+-------------------+
~~~~~~~~~~~

comments.author: chrysn
comments.body:
> Any compatibility issues with old and new implementations of 'kid'? 

Either way (kid2 or kid redefinition), a peer needs to know in advance
what the other can accept; KIDs are (AFAICT) currently not exchanged
in-band. Whoever knows enough of their peer to use a kid2 could use the
same knowledge to know that they support int-valued KIDs.

Trouble is where implementers come in anew and use numeric KIDs without
knowing that some peers may not support them -- that's a bit more
obvious with a kid2, but in the end I think in both cases it should fail
clearly at the KID distribution step (and if that's only "Sorry, I can't
enter that into my system, it expects a byte string and you gave me an
integer").

With an eye on code point usage (of 1..23, 10 are already assigned), I'd
prefer opening up kid, but ultimately that's something that ultimately
will need to be decided in COSE.

If COSE accepts the redefinition of kid then we simply replace kid2 with kid, otherwise we keep it.

issues.title: Effects of limited amounts of randomness
issues.author: chrysn
issues.body:
Randomness can be limited in constrained devices, and that can affect EDHOC.

8.2. Cryptographic Considerations does talk about the necessity of randomness, but it did not become apparent to me from reading that alone that without a new fresh key I not only lose liveness and open up to interleaving, but also run into loss of all security properties when deriving an OSCORE secret from it and neither party has any randomness to put in.

If one of the involved parties of EDHOC is just scraping together a few bits of entropy (which is as good as having none), is there a direction in which EDHOC can be used with limited loss of properties? (Gut feeling says no because an attacker can replay a previous EDHOC exchange with them).

It may be helpful to also outline how a monotonous counter (similar to that of OSCORE B.1.1) can be used together with a private secret to obtain sufficient randomness. (That may follow from RFC 8937 already, not sure).

comments.author: chrysn
comments.body:
Now having read a more recent version of the draft:

Looking further into the B.1.1 applicability, one way that'd to me gut-feeling-sounds like it might be OK is that the initiator only saves-to-disk its counter between receiving M2 and before sending M3.

Thus, an initiator might use the same ephemeral key twice, but before it completes the exchange, it ensures it will "never" use the same ephemeral key again.

---

The reason this would be useful is that it'd defer the point where the B.1.1 process performs a kind-of-destructive operation (writing to flash that has a finite number of duty cycles) to a point in time when it has good reason to believe that there is actually a peer that makes it worth it. (The response could still be replayed from an adversary that intercepted message_1 in an earlier iteration of this, stopped message_2 from reaching the device and then injected it now -- but that only gives the attacker one flash write for one time the attacker intercepts messages, and doesn't put the attacker in any better a position than other replays do).

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: @chrysn  What remains of this issue? Is there anything you want to add to the text?

EC types OKP and EC2 could have the same COSE header map label (TBD) but differ in content, like CRED_x as in EDHOC Section 3.3.3.

{ TBD :  CRED_x }

* For type OKP the CBOR map SHALL, except for subject name, only include the parameters 1 (kty), -1 (crv), and -2 (x-coordinate).

* For type EC2 the CBOR map SHALL, except for subject name, only include the parameters 1 (kty), -1 (crv), -2 (x-coordinate), and -3 (y-coordinate).

issues.title: State idempotency
issues.author: chrysn
issues.body:
When setting EDHOC up on a constrained CoAP library, it'd help a lot if there'd be a statement that the EDHOC operations must be idempotent, ie. tolerate that retransmissions of a request are passed on to EDHOC multiple times (ie. the CoAP library may forego request deduplication). Ideally, all these requests should lead to identical responses.

I think that these properties are already there (possibly necessitating that messages 2 and 4 are distinguishable by a server in initiator mode, if message 4 ever happens there); having a statement would make it possible to justify using EDHOC on a library like, say, RIOT's gcoap, in the first place.

comments.author: chrysn
comments.body: Tying this to the draft: "The transport is responsible to handle message loss, *reordering, message duplication*, fragmentation, and denial of service protection, where necessary". I think that EDHOC can do without the highlighted ones already.

comments.author: chrysn
comments.body: (Summarizing otherwise not-yet-written-down developments for chronology): It looks like it won't be "idempotency", but more something "the CoAP stack may forego message deduplication, because the EDHOC implementation needs to report back the last message when requested again".

comments.author: chrysn
comments.body: Looking at [I-D.ietf-ace-wg-coap-eap](https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-ace-wg-coap-eap-00), they face a similar situation -- but EAP expresses as a requirement for the lower layer that it must have ordered message transmission. I disagree with the mechanism they use (introducing a sequence number option; discussion ongoing), but maybe something comes out of the discussions there that'd help here as well; will keep this updated.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: @chrysn Could you please comment on the new text?

comments.author: chrysn
comments.body:
Sounds good, and well implementable. Two notes:

* Why does this need to be part of the applicability statement? Whether deduplication happens on CoAP level or on EDHOC level should be transparent to a well-behaved peer. (Plus, in the presence of proxies, even if one party does EDHOC level deduplication, there may actually happen CoAP level deduplication on the path -- but no well-behaved party would see the difference).

* On wording, it took me a bit to parse the "Note that if a different instance" sentence; suggested alternative to mix and match (with an addition of when this happens):

> Note that if two different versions of EDHOC message_x are received (message_x1 and message_x2, in that sequence), then the "processing" described above of message_x2 will produce the response to message_x1. That will correctly result in a failure in integrity verification due to difference in transcript hashes between the message_x instances. The situation can only arise when the peer violates the requirements of not processing a message twice, or when the messages are tampered with.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
About applicability statement: I believe you are right. I was thinking that if only one endpoint supports EDHOC message deduplication, the other endpoint would fail in case duplicate message appears. But actually, the other endpoint do need to support **some kind** of deduplication, it just doesn't matter which kind. So I'll remove that part.

On wording: I'll make another attempt.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
Not sure that this should be an appendix. If it is an appendix it should not be hidden behind the test vectors.

The suggested text states "duplication due to re-transmissions". What about other duplications? Duplication can happen anywhere in the network path. Or by an attacker.

"but the received message must not be processed more than once by the EDHOCimplementation. "

This is true for 2,3,4, not true for 1 and error. Needs to make clear that this is per instance.

issues.title: Opportunistic use
issues.author: chrysn
issues.body:
EDHOC looks to me like it should be usable in situations where one party has no need (or intention) to authenticate, but still wants to authenticate the other party or just use opportunistic encryption.

One use case might be a constrained device A obtaining the certificate indicated by device B in the A-B EDHOC exchange from the certificate URI at C indicated by B. A has no need to present credentials (C hosts the certs publicly), but doesn't want to reveal to passive evesdroppers that it's talking to B. It doesn't need to authenticate C, but that might still be a good idea to lock out active MITMs.

My impression is that this is possible with EDHOC as it is and that EDHOC is suitable for the task (if not, stop reading and tell me).

If it is suitable, would both of these work?
* Create (in COSE) a key ID type where a RPK that is CRED_x can be transported in ID_CRED_x (useful where you want to come back w/o having any original claims on first use)
* Have a key where your ID_CRED_x says "just what my ephemeral key is". That'd make exchanges just as compact as short-ID'd RPKs, and still be good-enough for unilateral authentication.

comments.author: chrysn
comments.body:
From just in the WG meeting: RPK-by-value sounds doable in COSE and would be good enough for a start.

The extended case is probably exceeding the LAKE requirements and is to be postponed.

(Personally I'd like to keep looking into it, if only to influence any left-over decisions that don't have any other influencing factors and one would rule this out -- but that can happen outside WG activity).

comments.body:
The more I think about this, the more I think that specifying a new type in the C509 draft is the right way to go.

- COSE_Key was not meant to be sent over the wire. It does not have a order and it is not very optimized.
- When working on issue #69 and PR #106 I realized that the singature curve has nothing to do with the signature alg and is completely detemined by the public key. It would be messy to have to types of public key formation and algorithms. Only using X.509 / C509 seems simpler in my view.
- A new type in C509 naturally allows optional sending of parameters like key usage, subject name, and life time, which might be useful in a RPK setting as well. 

Below is an example using the example certificate in the C509 draft. The type is changed to 2, the signature is removed, and all parameters are set to there minimum size. This PRK has key usage digital signature. Could be discussed if fields should be removed or have a non-present value.

The RPK has size 43 bytes:

2,
h'',
[],
null,
null,
[],
1,
h'02B1216AB96E5B3B3340F5BDF02E693F16213A04525ED44450
       B1019C2DFD3838AB',
1

Below is another example where a serial number, expiery time, and subject name (EUI-64) is provided, size 55 bytes.

h'0123456789AB',

h'02B1216AB96E5B3B3340F5BDF02E693F16213A04525ED44450B1019C2DFD3838AB',

issues.title: editorial / usability: corr and C_x omission
issues.author: chrysn

Both while trying to understand an implementation and in discussions of transport considerations, I was repeatedly had by the correlation numbers. It's convenient in the serialization to look into bits of a 2-bit number, but for talking about it, I always had to look things up.

Concrete proposal:

In the Message Correlation subsection, state after each bullet the respective one of "There is a C_x in the first message position", "In the first message position, C_I is sent and C_R is omitted", ..., "In the first message position, no C_x is sent". If phrased more concisely ("C_I is sent, C_R is omitted"), it'd need a paragraph that states that "The above statements about sending or omitting C_x only refer to the first positions in the messages; the C_I in Message 1 and C_R in Message 2 are always sent". Ideally, this could be put in a table.

Then, in the descriptions of Responder Processing of Message 2 and following, it can just say "C_x is sent depending on the correlation from {{}}".

IMO having these in one place and not baking the bit extraction in every step would make it easier to read.

The former is the data which is protected with keys obtained through the use of EDHOC, i.e. a straightforward application of EDHOC so the name "application data" is fairly intuitive. The latter is an extension point for use with security applications during EDHOC execution, like third party assisted authorization or certificate enrolment. 

Perhaps we should rename "auxiliary data" something with "extension"?
